Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned a lot about mythology. A LOT.

I learned about the rich and fascinating history of ancient Greece (WAY more complicated, by the way, than as presented in Percy Jackson!) as well as how to analyze Greek art - the different effects that the artifacts have, how the culture/economics/etc of a society changed the creation of artifacts, how the use of space, context of the object, use of color, etc. add to the overall representation of Greek myth, and how those representative choices reveal how the society/artist/etc. viewed the subject matter, and how that view is affected by economics, social environment, geography, etc.
I gained an appreciation for ancient Greek art from taking this class. I read a lot of classical mythology and learned how to identify gods and other figures in art.

This course was a lot different than basically any other course I've taken at Yale. It's really the first time I've spent extensive amounts of time examining art, and the first time I've had any take-home papers in a class. I learned how to examine and interpret ancient art in the context of Greek mythology, and advanced my ability to write about such topics.
I gained a much better and through understanding of Greek mythology which was a topic that I did not know much bout before.
I developed a better understanding of the art and myth in Greek history and had a better insight into my hobby of studying Greek mythology.

Learned extremely basic overview of Greek mythology and art. As someone who studied Greek mythology in high school and read the Percy Jackson series in middle school, I don't think I learned very much at all. We spent the first several weeks discussing the gods and their attributes, which were covered in a reading and are extremely basic. Not something a Yale course should spend that much time on.
Learned a ton of Greek myths
I learnt a lot about greek myth

I gained a deeper understanding of Greek myth as well as their origins and purpose. Additionally I gained skills to apply this knowledge to analyzing art, directly or indirectly depicting myths and forming ideas as to what this means about the art, artist, or society.
Knowledge of how to analyze ancient Greek art and texts. Readings of the Illiad and Odyessey, and how to relate them to art. Basic ancient Greek myths and stories.

I now know more about Greek Art and Myth than I ever knew I wanted to know (I want to go to Greece now). I also just feel that learning about culture is super interesting, and am glad I took this class.

I learned about Ancient Greek mythology and culture. 
My writing skills improved tremendously and I became a much more cultured person.
This class was very easy to engage in, the stories of Greek myth are incredibly interesting and it gave better insight into what ancient Greece was all about.
I learned a lot about ancient greek art and a little about mythology.
I learned a lot about Greek mythology and ancient Greek Art! Also how to write papers examining art.
This course gave a great overview of the culture and religion of Ancient Greece. I learned how to critically analyze art and write about it.
I learned how to analyze pieces of art by using techniques such as close-looking to find characteristics of different gods and mythological characters to identify them.
I learned so much more about Greek Mythology and how they appear on different art forms. I also learned how to write an art history paper.
I learned how to analyze art work, specifically in the context of Greek mythology.
Writing about art, cannon of greek myth, tying myth to art and recognizing the different ways myth is portrayed in art
Not much.

This course taught me many different Greek Myths and their significance in relation to art and Ancient Greek society. This course trained us to gain visual literacy, where we could identify figures in art pieces through their attributes and compare different art pieces focusing on the same mythological or historical figure. This course also taught us to compare different textual sources with the artworks, drawing commonalities and between artistic depictions with textual descriptions in line with the oral tradition of Greek mythology where different versions of myth exist and all are equally valid.

An introduction to all of the Greek myths that you had a vague introduction to as a child: Trojan War, the Olympians, Hercules, etc. With the additional coverage of lesser known gods (Dionysus is the best), religious sanctuaries in Greece, and ancient festivals. All the while looking at a lot of really cool, really really old art
I got really good at entering study terms into Quizlet, since you have to do that twice--once for the midterm, and once for final. That is the only skill I developed.
A thorough understanding of the major players and characters in Greek mythology and how they are all interconnected.
How to analyze art
I learned about Art and Myth in Greek Antiquity.
Greek myths
Learned how to interpret artwork and the stories they tell within the context of Greek mythology. I also learned a lot about Greek antiquity through archaic texts and works of art.

I had not had an extensive background in Greek mythology and art and this class taught me how to interpret Greek art very well. I never wouldve looked at Ancient Greek the way I do now thanks to this class.0
I learned a bunch of Greek myths and a decent amount about Greek art, especially vases.

Learned a ton ab out greek art and myth. Learned how to identify some famous pieces of art and to appreciate greek art influences in more modern art as well. Classes were focused around the themes of particular gods and myths, so we would read something about the god/myth then look at art relating to their story in class
Knowledge about ancient Greek myths and how they influenced culture during  Greek antiquity. Skills for analyzing art and connecting it to specific myths.
I learned a lot about the ancient Greek culture.

honestly don't know if I got any helpful skills from this class. memorized lots of art pieces. The writing style felt specific to art history and not particularly applicable to any other field which was a waste of time.

I learned more than I ever expected to about the identification of figures in Ancient Greek art, the types of Ancient Greek art (in terms of time period, style, and make and model of vases), and even a bit on architecture as well, such as regarding the Parthenon and the temple of Zeus at Olympus. However, the meat of this class is about comparing the art to myth, plays, and historical accounts-- by combining primary and secondary sources we were able to identify scenes portrayed on ceramics, find sculptures directly discussed in ancient texts, and figure out how plays relate to depictions of gods. All of these skills came together naturally through a combination of short readings, visits in sections to the Yale University Art Gallery, and detailed lectures full of interesting stories, images, and anecdotes.

I came to understand Greek art through the perspective of the literature. I had no idea how to perform a visual analysis of sculptures or pottery before taking this course and now can do so when I go to a museum.
I learned how to recognize art and recognize the myth that its was portraying. I learned about the stories of the myths as well as where they are told (what literature).
How to look at art and how it is a reflection of story.
I learned a ton about how to integrate art into historical/analytical papers and having had a TA who focused on public speech, I was able to better myself with that, as well.
I learned a lot about Greek mythology, particularly through art.
I learned much about ancient greek art and literature, and also how to read and analyze primary sources, identify figures in art, and how to connect written and visual sources.
This class taught me a lot of random details about Greek art and mythology, and also gave me the opportunity to read some classic works of literature.
ability to analyze ancient Greek pottery -- their material, painted figures, and plausible purpose

I greatly improved my visual literacy of Ancient Greek sculpture and vases, which means we can identify gods and goddesses, heroes, and specific myths in art. We studied Greek Mythology and saw how it was portrayed in art, focusing different themes. We learned about vase-painting and firing techniques and how they evolved over time as well as some famous painters, potters, and sculptures. Now, we have a good base of knowledge of the central pieces of art in Greek Antiquity, what they represent, and when they were made.

The course covered Greek mythology in art & in readings from antiquity! I had never studied or read anything regarding mythology & am very thankful to have taken this class! Not only was it enjoyable but I learned at lot!
Developed writing skills and analysis of art.
I gained a lot of visual literacy when it comes to Greek pots.

I learned a lot about the world of Greek mythology.
Moreover, I became more aware and observant of art pieces because of the variety of artwork we viewed during class.

Very good understanding of analyzing Ancient Greek art and Architecture, learned about the legacy of Greek myth in art and culture. I loved this class, if you did the readings and went to section and lecture it was truly a wonderful experience in the Classics/Art History departments.
Greek mythology, greek art, analyzing art
Understanding of Greek gods and myths, ability to make educated comments and analyses about ancient Greek art and the myths that are portrayed in these artistic representations
I learned a lot about Greek mythology and depictions both literary and artistic, as well as how Greek myth connected to the everyday lives of Ancient Greeks.

This course was so interesting and I learned a massive amount about Greek culture and the corresponding art. We learned about all aspects of Greek culture and also how to analyze greek art and architecture and their connections to ancient greek texts.
I developed the skills to recognize mythology in greek antiquity and the stories that these images tell.
greek mythology and some background in ancient greece
This was a fun class for me! Different from the rest of my usual course load- enjoyed learning about Greek mythology using art and antiquity!
I learned how to analyze images and art, particular ancient greek mythological art, from an art history perspective.
I learned a lot about Greek mythology
This course provided me with knowledge in Greek Mythology and the ability how to analyze works of art to gain more context to the stories they depict.
Knowledge of Ancient Greek myths and mythological characters, along with their artistic representations by painters and sculptors.
A great introduction to the most important texts from ancient Greece as well as many pieces from art and architecture
I have never learned about Greek mythology and thought it was very interesting
Learned about Ancient Greek myth and art

I learned about various aspects of ancient Greek culture and how they manifest in artistic objects. I also learned how they form the basis of and connect to todays western culture. Finding connections between (and comparing) textual evidence and visual art was an important skill developed in this class. In addition, I learned that myth is a collection of orally passed-down traditions and reflect the culture that it belongs to.
I learned a lot about ancient Greek literature and culture as well as its depictions in art.
This course pushed me to learn how to evaluate artwork and connect it to previous Greek myths.
The course provided in depth connections between ancient Greek life, art, and myth that students were encouraged to build upon on their own.
Greek myths and their representation in art
How to identify major figures and myths in ancient Greek art.
I learned to appreciate art from a different perspective, viewing it as a tool or expression for historical cultures.

I increased my basic knowledge of the myths of Greek antiquity, as well my knowledge of the way these myths informed the art and culture of Ancient Greece. I learned how to think about images and visual pieces of art alongside texts, traditions, and myths.
How to analyze and compare text and visual art pieces and more knowledge about how myth can be found in art.
I learned about Greek myths and how they are represented in art.
I felt like I gained a greater understanding of Greek Myths and the characters within them.
Extensive knowledge of mythology and art.
Deeper understanding of Greek mythology and how it is depicted in art/sculpture.
history of greek art and a lot of representations of greek art.
I learned a lot about greek art and how it connected to society and mythology.
Historical context and mythological basis for Greek art (pottery, temples, sculpture)
I learned about Greek myth and art, but it also helped me develop a timeline of Greek history and art styles.

We learned about all of the main figures in Greek mythology, their origins and the stories most often associated with them.  We also learned about some places in Greece where myth is tied particularly strongly to the physical place.  Throughout the course, we were shown artwork to learn the stories about the gods and see how they had fit into the Greek schema.
Greek mythology knowledge
Learned about important Greek history, myths, and mythological figures.
I learned a lot about Greek mythology and art and how it connects to modern day.
I learned about the Greek mythology and how to analyze the amphoras and statues from Antique Greece. I also learned how to construct an argument and write a paper about it.

The lectures were absolutely fascinating - I actually wanted to go to them (which I can't usually say about most of Yale's lectures). I feel like there could have been a bit more information on how to analyze the visual aspects of an artifact, especially since the final paper was on that aspect - the lectures and sections mostly related to the myths themselves, and the history of Greece - there wasn't as much about some of things that I was marked down on in my first paper (the shine of the paint, the method of creating the piece, the use of colors, etc.) and I felt a bit unprepared to go into the final paper.

It was solid all around
No complaints

The course is great. The only thing I didn't like was how I got squeezed out of a writing credit section, after Professor Gaifman reassured us that any and all students seeking a WR credit would get the opportunity to do so. But, the issue seemed like it was out of her control, so I don't fault her for this.

Other than this one little, nitpicky thing, the course was solid.

Weaknesses: lectures were a bit all over the place

Strengths: It was clear that Professor Gaifman was really into the topics we talked about making the class more engaging and fun. She also was very helpful with questions and responded to emails quickly.
The weaknesses are having a set understanding of the interpretations of the Greek art and grading the students based on that and not having it change from TA to TA.

Material was extremely low-level. Not particularly interesting or challenging. Most students took this as a gut, which is totally reasonable, but it would have been nice to learn things AND have little work, rather than just have little work. Never really felt engaged with the course.
Amazing great lectures no weaknesses
Lectures were very interesting

Lectures, readings, and sections were all valuable to me in my learning experience. These in addition to my limited mythological background helped me understand more of the implications of the myths, which I think is very important.

Some weaknesses are the range of material covered, because there is a lot to cover it is difficult to spend time in one area. So we would pick and choose which topics would be the ones we dived deeply in, but I felt that the ideas we passed over were just skipped. Additionally being a WR credit, there was not a lot of writing support and feedback related to craft, it still seemed very historical argument based grading and feedback-wise.

Interesting material, well organized, clear feedback.

Very specific grading on midterm.
Class is really good, lectures sometimes jump through too many subjects
This course was very easy to engage in and was very enjoyable to attend.

Overall this was a good and very interesting course. For the WR sections I could've used a little more writing support since with the exception of approving the final paper's thesis we were left mostly on our own to come up with papers. Maybe peer review session or TFs reading a paragraph or two would've been helpful. It would also be helpful to have a little more information on slides, because it's sometimes hard to tell what's important or what the main idea is. I would've also liked to learn a few more myths to go along with the artwork we looked at. I would also want my final essay back, just so that my final grade isn't as much of a mystery and so I can use those comments to improve future work. Overall I enjoyed the course though and it was definitely interesting.
The course has a good distribution of work throughout the semester and lectures are engaging and relevant to the coursework.

The course had a great structure. The lectures flowed well and the material was always very interesting. They did a great job organizationally despite the hiccups due to the course being oversubscribed.
The choice in TFs and perhaps a more structured way of grading across all the sections as some TFs have different criteria for the essays.
The material was very engaging and I enjoyed Professor Gaifman's lectures very much. Sections in the Art Gallery were really fun and entertaining.
The lectures and sections are very interesting, but I feel that the workload is not spread through the semester in the best way.
Section was not good. Class could be better taught.

The course was strong because it trained us well in looking at art and drawing arguments from the visual evidence to support ideas involving different aspects of Ancient Greek society. Professor Gaifman was also a really good lecturer and she ensured that lectures were interesting and instructive, allowing us to look at artworks from a different perspective for us to look at the artwork through different lenses and gain different conclusions from them. The course was weaker in the organization, there were too many assignments but not enough feedback for us to improve on our work between assignments. Sometimes the grading of the course seems arbitrary, where essays are not graded in the most fair and standardized manner due to the large size of the class.

This course gave a great introduction to Greek art and mythology. I learned how to write visual analysis of art and gained a greater appreciation for ancient art and mythology. I wish the class had explored some themes more deeply rather than just providing an overview of a lot of topics, but overall I really enjoyed the class.
Lecture slides could be a little boring and jumbled sometimes, although Professor Gaifman is very enthusaistic. The course material is awesome.
Too easy for anyone in the major, but otherwise fun

It's ideal as it is. It is like story time, where the professor reads some mildly interesting myth to you. Just captivating enough to be interesting, and just boring enough to allow you to get some nap time if you're tired in class.
The material was super interesting!

It's supposed to be a gut but honestly it's a lot of work. The exams are just kinda ridiculous exercises in memorization, and the professor cares a lot about memorizing specific dates for some reason. There shouldn't be both a final exam AND a final paper.
No WiFi in the stadium
Very fun and energetic instructor, as well as friendly and informative TA's. Would have liked to touch on the relationship between ancient Greek myths and modern pop culture a little bit more.
This class is very well taught and structured. The feedback on essays and tests was also very clear and concise.
It was pretty well-organized and structured. Expectations were pretty clear. Material was interesting and assessments were more than fair.
Amazing! I love it so much.

Strengths: Prof. Gaifman makes her expectations for the midterm and final extremely clear which is very helpful in studying. Although it is a lot of material, you know exactly what they will be looking for and how to exam will be structured. Very low pressure environment. There is a fair amount of time between each of the 3 writing assignments and ample time given on the midterm and final. Weaknesses: Was a bit rough having both a final paper and an exam in conjunction with my other exams.
Personally it was hard to keep up with the readings but the class was fascinating. It was hands-down my favorite class this semester.
This course was very well organized. The Professor was passionate about her topic and the TAs were also incredibly helpful.

I loved the content of the course, and Professor Gaifman was very engaging!

The main weaknesses came as a result of the class being so large. I heard that there was some disparity between TFs in terms of grading styles, something that is very difficult to overcome when there are so many students to grade for. It was also in the YUAG auditorium, so there were no desks and note-taking/test-taking was a bit of an inconvenience. That is all!

Not enough interaction between teaching fellows and students for writing sections. Expectations for writing were not clear and same for exams. My TA didn't even explain why I got points off on the midterm, there were just arbitrary point values lost, though she did say that she took off points for not completing a requirement of our that wasn't even mentioned in lecture or section, which is unfair. There are much better lectures and writing classes out there.

This course has no weaknesses, and is likely the best course I have ever taken at Yale. I say that as a science major.

The writing assignments, while short, built my descriptive skills and helped lower my dependence on adverbs. I received personal feedback from my TFs after every assignment, and each helped me synthesize information more effectively in the next.

My TF, Soffia, was incredible, and is probably the best TF I have ever had. She was very knowledgeable about Greek myth, and knew everything about the paintings and sculptures discussed. She made every discussion section worth walking from Science Hill to the YUAG worth it-- one particular example includes when we studied the symposium, she made us recline on our desks similar to how Greeks would have done. She provided us with information for the finals (such as a scanned glossary for a book recommended for the course but with most copies checked out from a library), she made sure each of us felt prepared for our papers, and she fought to have each of us improve, providing specific suggestions and incentives for doing so.

Professor Gaifman was also kind and wonderful-- I showed up to every lecture, which helped me a great deal on the final. The lectures went into great detail about the slides (which were available online), and she helped encourage comprehension. She peppered her lectures with jokes and stories, and made it easier to understand complicated texts such as the Iliad and Odyssey. She fought tooth and nail to increase the number of WR sections available to students, and I truly think she meant it. She sometimes did focus a bit too long on one topic, and the lecture would spill into the next, but she managed to transition effortlessly regardless.

The suggestion for improvement comes to the administration-- give this course the WR sections and TFs it deserves-- it is the most popular WR course at Yale and still had to turn some people away.

This is a great class! A great writing credit! The lectures are super interesting and the only assignments are the three essays and two exams. Instructions and guidance on writing and what to expect on exams were very clear.

The course provided a great survey of Greek art. Professor Gaifmann was really engaging and I attended nearly all lecture. Sometimes the material presented would be a little repetitive but overall this wasn't an issue. Also, the powerpoints posted to canvas were very unnecessarily long but that wasn't much of a hurdle. Would absolutely take another course taught by Professor Gaifmann in the future.

It could be improved by having slightly more organized lectures that followed a single train of thought. Lectures felt a little jumbled and seemed to jump back and forth from topic to topic and sometimes it was hard to see how they all related. However it was a super interesting class and I enjoyed the subject matter as a whole.
Loved lecture and how it was taught. It was super engaging hearing about the myths and how they were reflected in art.
I think the lectures could be more succinct and the section sign up should be done online to avoid the chaos that occurred when tons of students tried to manually sign up after lecture.

The lectures were great in this course! Professor Gaifman is a really dynamic professor, and she always makes the lectures fun and interesting. A weakness of this course is the TF's and the way the assignments are graded. I consistently felt that my assignments were graded overly harshly, even though I put more effort into this class than any of my other courses. For an "introductory" art history course, it definitely DISCOURAGED me from taking any other classes in the department for that reason.

A strength was Professor Gaifman - her enthusiasm and passion for the topic were very clear, and she always made the day's subject relevant to our everyday lives. Something that can be improved upon was the selection process for section. It was held in class at the end, and was pretty chaotic - I wasn't even sure if the section I initially singed up for fit in my schedule; I just wanted to get my name on a list. I think that signing up for section electronically would be better, especially given the volume of the class.

I liked that sections were held in the YUAG sometimes -- it was fun to see examples of art up close. In terms of weaknesses, I felt that the readings weren't completely necessary for doing well in the class, so it was pretty tempting to skip them.

strengths: enthusiasm of the professor, ability to pop over to the YUAG and talk about ancient pottery in front of some real-life examples, exciting essay topics, clear expectations for essays & exams, discussion of relevancy of Greek mythology to the modern world.

weakness: this class would be cooler as a smaller lecture since Prof. Gaifman is great and it's hard to get to know her in a lecture of 150+

The lectures were very interesting and closely followed the reading, which was great if you fell behind. Sometimes, sections met in the Gallery, and that was cool. We were given explicit instructions on how to study for the midterm and final exams, so it was not stressful to prepare for them. No noteworthy weaknesses, an excellent writing class.

The powerpoints could be more intuitive, especially when viewing them outside of the lecture. They were hard to follow. Sections could have been more writing focused and a day going over how to analyze art would have been helpful.
So great!!!
This course was a lot of fun and well designed in general. I loved having sections in the art gallery, and I think it would have been better to have almost all of them there!
This course is well taught and directed as it provides an overview of the most relevant pieces of information pertaining to Greek myth.

I loved that we utilized the YUAG for section, it made material much more engaging. The readings were really good and I wish we used some of them more in class. Overall, I thought the structure of lecture could have been improved, often we would spend 3/4 of the class covering what was meant to be covered last lecture then during the last 15 minutes we would get to the information about which the lecture was titled. It could have been organized more clearly in terms of theme, but the content was excellent.
Lectures and content were very interesting to learn and the class wasn't too much work! However, the lecture slides were not very organized or helpful so you have to go to lecture.

Strengths: both lectures and sections are engaging and informative, the questions on writing assignments and exams are fair

Weaknesses: The grading on exams is arbitrary. Grading is very subjective, and my TA was not able to explain why she took off the points that she did on my midterm exam. It is clear that some TAs grade much more harshly than others, but the professor does not seem to account for that in calculating grades.
The lectures were engaging, but I wish we had spent more sections in the art gallery, especially because I felt like the sections were often repetitive of what was talked about in lecture.
There could perhaps be a little more analysis on how to analyze art in a paper and how to write an effective art history paper.
The material of this course was very interesting and the lectures were as well.
strengths: interesting material, relatively low workload, lectures were entertaining; weaknesses: didn't really improve my writing, lectures on ancient greece weren't as interesting

Its a good course. It can be very difficult, however, to tell what the expectations are for what you should do on exams. Making that more clear from the getgo would make the course seem more cohesive and less unnecessarily stressful.
There were lots of strengths to this course and not any weaknesses I can think of
The main weakness of this class was the large lecture size.
Strengths are a balance of myth and art, but weaknesses are lack of putting things together and identifying recurring themes, until the end of the course.
The lectures were really interesting and the sections were fun and engaging
I thought it was really strong and I loved each lecture

The lectures were very interesting and Prof. Gaifman really knows how to package information in an interesting way. With that said, the lecture slides themselves were not very useful for studying. Most of the information needed for the exams were mentioned orally in class, so taking notes were very important. Perhaps that could be stressed a little more in the beginning of the semester.
One concerning thing I have noticed is that grading seemed to differ quite a lot depending on the TA. Some of my friends consistently got As and some got Bs, despite our similar contents on the midterms. Some TAs were really strict in grading the midterms and papers, and I think sometimes they were pretty unreasonable (such as docking points off for not identifying which book of the Iliad/Odyssey that a mythological episode is from). I think there could be a better standardization of grading.

The lectures were fascinating, and the readings were always very informative and short considering how much they contained. The discussion section was useful for helping us analyze literature and art ourselves in a guided fashion, and having section in the art gallery itself was a lot of fun.

This course really depends on your TF, I really enjoyed the course material and felt like it was manageable because my TF made it very easy for us to succeed. However, I do know of other students who were not as fortunate.
Best class at Yale. No question about it.
This course was very well structured, the lectures were always very straightforward and I ended up learning more than I realized. Sometimes the lectures would get a little repetitive.
It has a great deal of reading that can be unrealistic at times. The class is very interesting, and lectures are enjoyable.

This course is well organized and reasonably paced. The material is important and fascinating. My only wish would be for slightly more engagement with primary texts as strange and elusive entities in themselves, not as straightforward aids to visual interpretation (although the course is, of course, not primarily focused on texts).
I think the strengths of the course were the many discussion sections in the YUAG and how much info was presented in the course.

I thought the lectures were very interesting. I loved every one.  The only annoying thing was that there was no WiFi in the auditorium and the slides were not posted on Canvas until after lecture so it was hard to record the images Professor Gaifman was talking about. I also wish there were more writing sections or that the registration process was shorter and better organized. By the time I found out I had not gotten into a writing section, Reading period was almost over.
I felt like the course had a solid introductory approach, and it was well designed to facilitate learning for students of all backgrounds.

Strengths: Very interesting subject matter

Weaknesses: Examinations sometimes emphasized memorization over analysis (analysis of art pieces) I feel
This class was amazing. The lecture style was wonderful and engaging. The only improvement I would make is the timeliness of returned grades.
I liked the topics but thought that talking about the same vase for 40 slides out of the lecture was a little boring. Looking at more examples could have been more interesting.
It was very interesting and the way it was presented was great.
Awesome lectures, classroom section was pretty underwhelming when compared to the advantages of section in the YUAG
Lectures were very slow

Professor Gaifman is amazing  she is a really engaging lecturer and seems really nice and approachable.  She and the team of TAs did so much work at the beginning of the course securing more sections for the class so that more people could take it as a writing credit, which I know a lot of people appreciated.  I loved lectures because we were always learning about something interesting.  Some of the reading seems extraneous and not really necessary, but some are truly fascinating and are different from the myths that we might have been used to reading.  Personally, I really liked that the writing sections and non-writing sections had different requirements because I had to write one less paper.  Another great thing was how often we had section in the art gallery; I always need more excuses to hang out in there.  For the final paper we had a lot of freedom in choosing our topic, so we could really delve deeper into something we were interested in.  One weakness was the review session for the final exam; I am not sure if there was one for the midterm, but this one was terrible.  It was not well organized and the only helpful information we got was the format of the exam and how much time to spend on each thing, which I did not end up sticking to because it was dumb.  The TA who led it seemed like she did not know what she was doing.  At one point, she told us not to ask her specific questions because she might not know the answer...
The material was very interesting but going to class didnt provide any extra information.

Strengths: very interesting content, lectures were interesting, visits to YUAG were exciting
Weaknesses: difference in difficulty of TAs

The strengths: Prof Gaifman is very enthusiastic about this class and it shows! She also tries to accommodate everyone's needs. The class is fun and rather chill compared to other high intensity Yale courses.

strengths- interesting
weaknesses- not very engaging
Yes, this is a fun WR class.

This is an amazing 5th class! The lectures are absolutely fascinating, but you can skip if you're overwhelmed or don't have time, and will still do fine in the class - the lectures are posted, and the information is very easily accessible. I did the non-WR credit option, so the writing was limited, and pretty easy, and the midterm/final were not terrible either! The best part of this class is the absolutely fascinating material! You'll learn a lot about history, and feel ready to talk about Greek art and how that relates to Greek history and myth, and you'll also understand how much ancient Greece has influenced modern society!
I would recommend this class because it is really interesting to take what you already know about Greek mythology and take it to the next level.

I would recommend this course to other students (especially STEM students looking for a gut HU or WR).
Material was interesting, and the workload was minimal.

I'd highly recommend this course to another student. It's a lot different than a lot of other courses here, and it's honestly a more fun topic than most. The Greek gods can be an enjoyable topic.

I'd especially recommend if you can get into a writing section.
Yes, especially if your interested in/ want to learn more about Greek mythology. Professor Gaifman is amazing!!
Yes because if they enjoy learning about myths like me then they will enjoy the stories and art we discuss in class.

I'd recommend this to students who are unfamiliar with Greek culture/art and interested in learning about it, as this class would be a gentle introduction. Otherwise, the only demographic interested in this course is likely students looking for an easy HU/WR credit.
Yes

This is definitely an enjoyable course if you want to learn about greek mythology or want to know more. I really enjoyed my time studying for the exams as well as writing the more creative final paper where you get to compare myth to almost any other fictionalized work of art. This last part really emphasized how pervasive Greek myths are to the rest of human history or maybe how universal the myths are. Also a WR credit if you can get it and Professor Gaifman is super passionate and really good in lecture.

If you want a writing credit, or are interested in Greek mythology or ancient art, I think this class is pretty good. Reading parts of the Iliad and Odyssey and then relating them to art was very fun and being able to analyze figures in ancient art was interesting. Workload is not bad at all, but lectures and section discussion can sometimes be boring/repetitive.
If you're not interested in Greek art and myth and are looking for a easy writing credit, I would warn you that this is actually more work than I expected. That being said, I would still
Yes. This is one of the best courses I've taken not related to my major or career interests.
Yes, this class was very interesting and Professor Gaifman was great.  It is a great class for a WR credit as well because it gives interesting topics to write about.
Yes! Interesting material, reasonable workload, and a fun way to learn about the Classics and ancient Greek myth.

Yes. It was a really fun and interesting class to take. Professor Gaifman's enthusiasm for the subject makes every lecture enjoyable, and the sections held in the YUAG were great. It was definitely an amazing class to engage with the gallery's collections.
Yes, this course was a lot of fun and I got to read interesting mythological stories then tie that to images of vases and monuments around the world.
Yes, if you're even the slightest interested in Greek mythology or just need a painless WR credit.
Yes, it is interesting. But a lot more work than expected.
Yes! If you like art history, but aren't an art history major, this is a great option to learn about something a bit more niche while still staying in the realm of intro classes.
No. The profoesssor and teaching assistants are terrible.

I would recommend this course to another student given that they know the amount of work that goes into doing well in this class. Unless you already know all of greek mythology, you will likely learn many different and sometimes seemingly obscure myths and there is a lot of reading and writing involved with this class. However, if you put in the work and really enjoy learning about greek myth academically, this can be a rewarding class where you turn an interest into an academic field that you learn a lot from.
Yes, I would. It's a really fun and interesting course for anyone interested in Greek mythology.
At 15-20 pages for the semester, this was a interesting, low stress writing credit for me. If you are remotely interested in ancient Greek mythology this is a must take

Yes. Take this class. 

Prior to this past semester, I thought guts at Yale were like unicorns; I entered freshman year hoping they existed, as my mom constantly promised me through high school. These beautiful, effortless creatures dominated both my conscious thought, and my subconscious; on the nights before difficult STEM exams, I would dream of these storied creatures, hoping one day to not spend my Wednesday night in Starr and instead sending it on the dance floor at Woads, or perhaps at a Leisurely soiree in the basement of a Lynwood street house. After going through four semesters of disappointment, still failing to identify a true, thoroughbred unicorn gut, I was ready to call of my search. 

I started to suspect I found a unicorn a few weeks into the semester. After being berated with hour after hour of bland STEM equations and economic jargon from my classes earlier in the day, I was easily soothed into a deeply relaxed state by Professor Gaifman as she spoke of athletic demigods, beautiful goddesses, and generally incredible tales. No one forced me to memorize an equation. No one forced me to participate in lecture. No one asked me to do a proof, or remember that log(1+r) approximates to log(r). 

My eureka moment of the true guttiness of this class came after the Professor Gaifman sent us the study guide for the midterm. A list of around 20 terms and 8 photos of works of art was included. The test was a regurgitation, asking us to simply re-write four of these terms and identify two of these photos. No critical thinking was involved. I did not have to make decisions or problem solve--I spewed out the information and got nearly 100%. The final was similarly easy. 

Each of the three papers required us to look at a work of greek art, usually a big wine mixing cup, and literally just describe what it looked like. These papers were similar to teaching a child new vocabulary. While I don't yet have a child of my own, I've seen parents point their children excitedly to an airplane flying by, exclaiming "Aiiiirrrplaaaane," and maybe if the child were especially advanced, saying, "see the wings," and even, "what big engines it has!" Of number of mythological figures visible on the first work of art, I could only identify two of them. No worries! Just say, "this blob is person shaped. This person has dark skin--it's a man. This man is naked. This man is so ripped--like the most ripped. This man probably a god because he's tall." That earned a solid A. For the last two papers, you just do this for two works instead of one, and compare these descriptions. 

Taking this class is like sipping the drink of your choice on the beach of a tropical island as a beautiful human fans you with the stiffest of palm fronds, overlooking clear waters and light onshore breezes. Upon finishing the final exam, I made my last beautiful realization; I learned a lot about Greek Myth and its depictions in Ancient Greek Art. Now I can casually drop a reference at a cocktail party, if I'm ever lucky enough to be invited to one, reminding everyone that I, by the way, did attend Yale University. I can look at a statue or a painting, and say, "Hey! That's Zeus. Or maybe Poseidon. Or Athena. Definitely a Greek God though!" The uselessness of this information is unparalleled, but the ease with which Professor Gaifman led us to learn this information is similarly astounding. Please, take this class. Oh, and it's a writing credit.
Yes. Very interesting material and not very taxing whatsoever in terms of the workload. You will learn with no real stress hanging over your head.

I thought the class was amazing! I honestly took it as a fifth class because it seemed manageable and I was right. The material is very fascinating, especially because I have always found Greek mythology interesting. The workload was low, so a lot of people skipped lecture because it wasn't super necessary to do well in the class. I think this is a class where you get what you put into it -- if you're just looking for an easy class you could probably get an A in this class and learn nothing. If you really engage with the material though, you'll probably feel much more comfortable with art history / art analysis by the end of the class.
Not really. There are easier guts and the exams were just a hassle.
Yes! If youre interested in Gerri myths
Yes, fun and interesting course with a great instructor.

Yes! This is a very interesting yet not very intellectually challenging course. The essay topics are very broad and easy to expand on as well. Great way to get a WR or HU without stressing too much about workload.
Yes! It was interesting and not a lot of work!
Hell yeah boi best class of my career

Absolutely! Super interesting material and not too much work. The readings were all pretty brief and always interesting. The papers were also very open ended, so there was a lot of freedom to write about things you find interesting. Great WR!

TAKE THIS CLASS!! It is so much fun and you will learn so much more than you ever expected. You will be able to relate the information you learn about the 7th - 4th century BCE to modern day phenomena, which is so cool. I definitely have become a Greek Antiquity geek. Millet Gaifman is such an engaging and FUN lecturer. She likes to focus on sex, wine, and the physical physique of Greek antiquity figures, which made going to lecture so enjoyable.

YES!!!
It was truly fascinating. The myths we discussed were very interesting but the connection that was made between them and ancient Greek art was very insightful. The class was at the YUAG, so the fact that some of the pieces we discussed in class were so close to us was amazing.

Yes! This class is not incredibly time consuming but you learn a lot about the Greek gods and the art that they are depicted on. If you have any interest in Ancient Greek history and evaluating are take this class.

As someone who has never really possessed an interest in Greek mythology, this course was the perfect introduction and it ended up being my favorite class of the entire semester. Professor Gaifman is a passionate and exciting individual who cares about sharing her love for Greek myth so that her teaching stems from the heart. The material is engaging and presented in a way so that learning integrates fun.
Not really. I've been to much better lectures. The slides weren't that helpful. TAs weren't helpful either and made class more troublesome than necessary.

TAKE THIS COURSE.

It is an easy WR and Hu, but the reasons for taking it go far beyond that. 

Professor Gaifman is a sweetheart and she made it very clear she wanted us to succeed-- from gestures like writing "may the gods be with you" on our exams to giving extensive information on testable objects, I always felt confident in the class. Despite its large size, every lecture felt like a 12-person seminar-- while we were not called on individually, she encouraged us and let us answer as a class, and helped grow our confidence in the process. She LOVES Greek art and myth it really shows-- the passion she has for the subject is unbelievably high. 

For a class that takes most of its students from people who read Percy Jackson as kids, it was great watching our casual knowledge and interest blossom when exposed to more advanced material like parts of the Iliad or the Bacchae. I felt like my passable knowledge in Greek myth and art is now highly developed, and I feel like I could confidently go into a museum and give a summary on most Greek works I came across.

It combines historical events with myth, and gave context to buildings such as the Parthenon in the process. Sections delve into topics that may appear on essays or texts, but they do so in an enjoyable manner-- one such example included going to the Yale Art Gallery (as half of our sections did) and describing a sculpture of Aphrodite to our peers, who would then draw what we talked about-- that helped improve our descriptions a great deal.

Every second of this class was a joy. It was held in a room without WiFi, but it remains the only course at Yale where I did not feel bored enough to check my phone-- I was interested the whole way through. 

If you have ANY interest in writing, art, myth, or Greek history, take this class. You will not regret it.
This class is super fun! I would definitely recommend it to anyone who needs a writing credit (particularly good for stem majors since no humanities background is required)

I would recommend this course to any art lover. Going in, I thought it would be a vaguely interesting WR credit but I have come to appreciate Greek art in a way I didn't know how to prior to taking this course. Even the required sections were fun.

yes I would recommend this to another student. it was not particularly hard and the workload was very manageable. Additionally the subject matter was super interesting and engaging. It was like listening to stories over and over. I got the most out of it by going to class and paying attention to all of the lectures. I would definitely recommend doing that. It will make everything easier and your experience more enjoyable.
Yes, a great way to get a writing credit in an interesting topic.
I would recommend this course! Especially with my TA, Bo.

I would not recommend this course if you are trying to get a relatively low-work writing credit. It is a huge amount of work. Three essays (one of which is 10 pages), a midterm, and a final. It felt so hard to do well in this class, regardless of how much effort I put into my work. My TF was very harsh and didn't give me good feedback on what I can improve upon. Honestly, this class caused me more stress than any of my other courses, all of which are STEM. Honestly I would not recommend this, even though the lectures are great.

I would for sure recommend the course. Even if they aren't an art history major they can still gain an appreciation for ancient greek art and the beauty in the sculptures and depictions. It's also pretty light in terms of work load, and a good writing credit for those who need it.
If you're interested in Greek art and mythology, yes!
absolutely. fun because of the content, unique among other universities because of the YUAG visits
Yes, because the Instructor was very spirited and this made going to class very enjoyable. Also, the switch-up between where sections were held were nice and exciting.

Yes, the course is a great survey of Greek Art from about eighth-century B.C.E. to second-century B.C.E. Also, it included mythology which I find interesting. It was like an interdisciplinary art history and literature course with emphasis on the art. Excellent choice for a writing credit. You will want to go to the lectures as they are useful and interesting.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! I did not know any Greek mythology before & had a fun time in the class!
Fantastic class, really learned a lot of Greek Myth.

Yes!!!!! Such a fantastic class! Prof Gaifman gives the most enthusiastic, passionate lectures and truly made me fall in love with myth and Greek art! I almost changed my major to art history or classics even though Im a junior! Shes amazing and its so great that we learn from art at the YUAG. Take this class as a WR or HU credit for sure!
Yes, take this course. It is fun and you get to learn a lot about Greek mythology.
Yes this course is great for an intro art course or if someone wants to expand their knowledge of the ancient Greek gods and goddesses.
Yes, especially if interested in exploring Classics and Art History
I would recommend for an interesting writing credit!

Yes. You learn a lot about Hreek mythology and develop the ability to write well about Ancient Greek art. However, the exams are very memorization-heavy and the grading on exams is unfair and arbitrary, so dont take the class if you really care about getting an A.

Greek mythology is still so important in our world today, so I think developing a strong backing in it is really interesting and relevant. A lot of people have a basic knowledge of Greek myth, but it was really interesting to be able to go deeper and learn the actual stories and the places and art that are related to them. The expectations of the class are also very clear and reasonable, which makes the class lower-stress, and I actually enjoyed writing the final paper!
I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially anyone interested in Greek art and culture.
Yes, the material is very interesting and fun to learn.
yes, great for a writing credit if your not a big fan of writing/humanities and lectures and reading were entertaining
Yes! Take this course! Just fun things to learn!
Yes! If you like greek mythology, you owe it to yourself to take this course.
Yes it was a very interesting course
I would recommend this course to any students interested in Greek Mythology.

Yes, but with the writing credit. It was overall pretty interesting, especially pairing artistic representations with textual myths. Many visits to YUAG, yet the lectures are sometimes hard to get through.
Yes, absolutely! This was a great and fun course and is perfect even for someone with no prior experience with art history or Greek mythology
Yes! Interesting material and fun professor
Yes

I thought that this course would be a gut, because everybody told me so. Its not a gut  but it isnt exactly too much work either. Expect to do just as much as in any other class, and its not too bad for a writing credit. The challenging part isnt really writing papers, but the exams. There is so much information to learn, and you have to write down literally everything that is mentioned in lecture in addition to everything mentioned in the readings. Get one detail slightly wrong or forget to include a detail, and you will get your score deducted. With that said, the material covered is really interesting and important to learn in order to understand western culture. Take it if you are interested in ancient culture and how it forms the foundation of western culture today. Just know that this class is a lot more art history than myth.

I would highly recommend this course to another student, as it was one of my favorites here at Yale. The course material itself is already interesting, but everything from the lectures to the sections to the additional readings really help bring it to life.
Absolutely. Loved it
Yes, but definitely be aware that your experience can vary depending on your TF.
Absolutely. Ton of fun and prof is a g. Really good mix of interesting myth/history and art. Get to go to the yuag for some sections
Yes! I have such a greater appreciation for Greek myth now and how it is manifested not just in art, but in literature and film
Yes it is a great writing credit with really interesting and fun material.

I would recommend this to someone who is interested in art history but might not be an art history major. The myths and figures we discuss in class are very familiar in popular culture which makes the class' subject relevant and interesting.
Yes, and I have to several friends.
Yes! Greek Art and Mythology is wonderful, interesting, beautiful, engaging, complex, and quintessential to the formation of modern society and modern norms. This class should be required.
100% recommend
